title: ISic001325. Epitaph for Sosia Elate
body:
Facsimile Images

Σοσίᾳ ( vac. 2) Ἐλάτῃ
γλυκυτάτῃ
Ἀφροδείσιος
σύμβιος

Apparatus criticus

Text based on photographs; Korhonen observes that the name of the deceased could be in the nominative form, but the presence of the attribute suggests that it is dative.

English translation

To the sweetest Sosia Elate, Aphrodeisios, her husband.

Italian translation

Alla dolcissima Sosia Elate, Aphrodisios, il marito.

commentary

The epitaph presents a less common structure, with the name of the deceased probably in dative and the name of the dedicant in nominative followed by an attribute that qualifies his relationship with the deceased (see Korhonen 2004: 87). To be excluded is the interpretation of the epitaph as two nominatives, the first of the name of the deceased, the latter of the name of the dedicant because of the attribute γλυκυτάτη. The indication of the age of the deceased and the dedication verb is omitted. The gentilicium Sosia testifies that the deceased belonged the gens Sosia; her cognomen Ἐλάτη is also attested in an inscription of imperial age from Dikaiarchia-Puteoli (CIL 10.2209). The name of the husband, Ἀφροδείσιος, is well attested in several inscriptions of South Italy (LGPN 3A: 86).

bibliography

  • Gualtherus 1624 [1625] no.45 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001931
  • Amico 1741 246 no.1 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002186
  • Torremuzza 1769 142 no.43 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002084
  • Torremuzza 1784 149 no.50 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002083
  • Ferrara 1829 345 no.1 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002005
  • 14.0504 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001072
  • 129 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000028
  • 3.5706 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001252
  • Libertini 1930 73 no.152 ph https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001871
